chunks.text: Hey, everybody, so I guess in today's topic I'm gonna be explaining nested loops it looks like so a nested loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Think of it as a loop found within the code of another loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You have a loop right any code within that loop is indented underneath that loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, you could have a looping structure found within the code of another looping structure

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The loop on the outside is the outer loop the internal loop within the outer loop is known as the inner loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Where you'll encounter nested loops it's really situational

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You can have a while loop inside of a while loop before loop inside of a for loop

chunks.title: co

chunks.text: Well, hello everybody today. I will be explaining a few different types of collections in python

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There's four general purpose collections three of them are lists sets and tuples

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: There are also dictionaries, but I'll save that for the next topic because they can be kind of tricky

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A collection I would think of them as a single variable and I'm saying that within quotes that is used to store

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Multiple values. That's how I would explain a collection to a beginner

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For example, let's say we have a variable variable

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Fruit fruit equals some value like apple and then I can print this fruit

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Which is apple I could turn this variable into a collection

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: By surrounding my values with either a set of square brackets for a list curly braces for a set or parentheses for a tuple

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's begin with the list

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I would like to store more than one value in this variable, I will surround my values with the set of square brackets

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This variable is now a list. I can store multiple values separated with a comma

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Not only do we have an apple in this variable, but we have an orange

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A banana

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And coconut

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: One naming convention that I like to use if I declare a collection such as a list set or tuple

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I like to take the variable name and make it plural just so that it's more obvious that this is a collection of values

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Technically in the English language fruit would still be plural English is a weird language

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We now have a list of fruit named fruits

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I were to print my list

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: This is the result

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We have all of our values enclosed with a set of square brackets

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To access one of these elements found within your list

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You can use the index operator much like what we can do with strings

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The first element would have an index of zero

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would print my value apple

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Index of one would be my orange

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Two is banana

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Three

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Coconut

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What about four?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We don't have a value there

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: List index out of range

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Each value in a collection is also known as an element

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If we attempt to access an element that's not found within our collection

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You'll run into an index error

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: With the index operator

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You could set a beginning index

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: An ending index and a step

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I would like the first three elements

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You could say zero

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Cole in

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Three

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That would give me apple orange banana

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Technically you don't even need the zero

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You'd need that colon though

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I would like every second element

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co

We don't have a value there List index out of range Each value in a collection is also known as an element If we attempt to access an element that's not found within our collection You'll run into an index error With the index operator You could set a beginning index An ending index and a step I would like the first three elements You could say zero Cole in Three That would give me apple orange banana Technically you don't even need the zero You'd need that colon though We can even use a step I would like every second element Apple banana It's every second element beginning from index zero Maybe I would like my fruit backwards I'll set the step to be negative one Coconut banana orange apple You can use the index operator With collections much like you can use with strings Another cool thing you can do too with collections Is that you can iterate over them with the for loop For x in my collection fruits What would we like to do? I will print whatever x is So we have iterated over our list Apple orange banana coconut Now x isn't really too descriptive What you'll see some people do Is that with their collection name it's plural Their counter will be the singular version of that word If our collection name is fruits Let's rename x as fruit singular It's not mandatory but that's a common convention It's more readable that way For every fruit in fruits If this were cars you could say for car in cars Our counter is storing whatever value is within our collection So what are all the different methods that we can use with collections To list the different methods that are available to a collection You can use the Dure function Within this function add your collection fruits But we wouldn't need to print this Let's surround this function with a print statement These are all in alphabetical order We have attributes which I have not explained yet But I will in a future topic But if we scroll to the end We have a bunch of different methods that this list can perform A pen, clear, copy, account, extent, index, insert, pop, remove, reverse And sort If you would like a description of each of these methods There is a help function Help add your collection to the parentheses Then we would need to print this Here's the description of all the methods and attributes For example we have our sort method And here's the description Sort the list in ascending order and return none And then a bunch of other stuff If you ever forget what you're capable of with a list or other collection You can always use the help function To print a description of the attributes and methods available If you need the length of how many elements are within a collection There is the length function Return the length of my list fruits Then let's print it There's four elements within my list The length function returns for If I were to add an extra element like a pineapple Then that number would be five Let's remove that Using the in operator we can find if a value is within a collection Is our value apple in fruits But then we would need to print this This operator will return a boolean So let's print whatever that is Is apple in fruits That is true But is pineapple Pineapple is not it's false You can use the in operator to find if a value is within a list And that applies for your other collections too With lists they're ordered and changeable Duplicates are okay We can change one of these values after we create our list Let's take fruits at index of zero I will set this equal to be a pineapple Then let's iterate over our fruit Using a for loop Okay the first element is no longer an apple It's a pineapple Then orange banana coconut Using an index you can reassign one of the values Power to change zero to one Well now we have an apple pineapple banana coconut Let's cover some of the methods that are found within a list We can append an element Type the name of the list Dot Append What would we like to append to the end of this list Let's append a pineapple I'm going to get rid of this for loop I'm just going to display my list There we have it
